dc:description:
TNFSF11 gene is located on chromosome 13 at 13q14.11 and encodes the tumor necrosis factor ligand superfamily member 11 protein which plays a crucial role in several biological processes, particularly in bone remodeling, immune function, and the formation of mammary glands during pregnancy (PMIDs: 37893470, 32850393). One disease assertion has been reported in association with this gene: osteopetrosis, autosomal recessive 2 (MIM:259710, MONDO:0009816). Per criteria outlined by the ClinGen Lumping and Splitting Working Group, there was no evidence of differences in molecular mechanism, phenotypic variability, and inheritance pattern. Therefore the following disease entity has been lumped into one entity: TNFSF11 and TNFSF11-related osteopetrosis (MONDO: ID requested). 

TNFSF11 was first reported in connection with TNFSF11-related osteopetrosis in 2007 (Sobacchi et al. 2007 PMID: 17632511). Patients with this disease may present with optic atrophy, blindness, cranial nerve involvement, hydrocephalus, severe cerebral bulbar deterioration, severe growth inhibition, severely impaired and/or delayed dentition with chronic parotid/mandibular abscess, short stature, hepatosplenomegaly, anemia, hypocalcemic seizure, and hypocalcemia (PMID: 34056870). 

Six variants (2 frameshifts, 2 missense, 1 deletion, 1 splice site) reported in four publications have been included in this curation (PIMDs: 39011244, 34056870, 23762088, 17632511). This gene-disease relationship is also supported by two non-human model organisms (PMIDs: 10984520, 22068587), protein interaction (PMID: 22664871), biochemical function (PMID: 32850393), skeletal and extraskeletal expression (PMID: 9568710), and rescue in a non-human model organism (PMID: 23762088). 

In summary, there is definitive evidence supporting the relationship between TNFSF11 and TNFSF11-related osteopetrosis. The classification was approved by the ClinGen Skeletal Disorders GCEP on meeting date 12/02/2024 (SOP Version 11)

evidence.dc:description: Patients with TNFSF11 - Related Osteopetrosis present with delayed dentition, severe osteopetrosis, growth inhibition, and hepatosplenomegaly, features that are recapitulated in this mouse model.
evidence.rdfs:label: Douni_AROmouse

evidence.dc:description: Patients with TNFSF11 - Related Osteopetrosis present with skeletal dysmorphisms such as severe osteopetrosis, absent osteoclast, delayed dentition, and severe bone deformities, features that are recapitulated by this mouse model.
evidence.rdfs:label: Kim_knockout mouse model

evidence.dc:description: The 1 mg/kg dose proved to be able to almost completely rescue the bone defect, by restoring osteoclast differentiation and resorption. The 1 mg/kg dose importantly improved the hematolymphoid compartment of the treated Rankl −/− mice, with a restoration of the hematopoietic function within the bone marrow and an improvement of splenic and thymic architecture.
evidence.rdfs:label: Treating Rankl −/− mice with subcutaneous injections of RANK

evidence.dc:description: Patients with TNFSF11 - Related Osteopetrosis present with absent osteoclast, abnormal skeletal system, bone fractures, and abnormal T cell proliferation. These are features that can be explained due to TNFSF11 gene function disruption by germ line mutations.
evidence.rdfs:label: Ming_Bone homeostasis and immune system regulation

evidence.dc:description: Luan et al. reported the 2.7-angstrom crystal structure of the human TNFSF11 trimer in complex with the N-terminal fragment of human TNFSF11 containing 4 cys-rich TNFR homologous domains (OPG-CRD). Structure-based mutagenesis and surface plasmon resonance analysis showed that the RANKL trimer uses 3 equivalent grooves between 2 neighboring monomers to interact with 3 OPG-CRD monomers symmetrically.  The results revealed that OPG exerts its decoy receptor function by directly blocking the accessibility of important interacting residues of TNFSF11, for TNFRSF11A recognition.
evidence.rdfs:label: Luan_structure-based mutagenesis & surface plasmon resonance

evidence.dc:description: Evidence of skeletal and extraskeletal expression of the gene.

TNFSF11 expression in embryos is localized in the spleen (focally), thymic medulla (focally), developing lymph nodes (diffusely), and intestinal lymphoid patches. TNFSF11 expression in the adult was also found in the same lymphoid tissues. Expression in the skeleton is detected in the primitive mesenchymal cells surrounding the cartilaginous anlagen and in hypertrophying chondrocytes within the anlagen. Additional  expression includes primary ossification and modeling in the developing femur. In normal adult bone, highest expression is detected in the region of the primary spongiosa, localized to cells associated with the metaphyseal vessels and hypertrophic chondrocytes. High levels of TNFSF11 expression are also detected in spindle-shaped mesenchymal cells in the metaphyseal.
evidence.rdfs:label: In situ hybridization

evidence.dc:description: The mutation is seen in families 2 and 4 in this publication as well as families S5 and S6 in the Lo Iacono et al. 2013 PMID: 23762088 article. This variant is scored once to avoid overweighting it's impact to the disease.
Yes (Crockett et al 2011 PMID: 20458572 could not draw definitive conclusions regarding the possibility that the mutant products maintain a residual activity or rather completely lose their function.

evidence.rdfs:label: Sobacchi_Pt4
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: T cell proliferation and propensity to apoptosis

evidence.dc:description: Upgraded by 0.5 points for x-rays demonstrating the severity of the bone phenotype. Downgraded by 1.0 points for homozygosity and consanguineous parents.

evidence.rdfs:label: Lo lacono_Subject 7
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: mild cerebral atrophy, severe bone deformities involving all skeletal segments, hypoplasia of the facial, profound involvement of the spine, knees and legs, and recurrent pulmonary and upper airway infections. Patient received a first HSCT from an HLA-matched family donor at 2 years of age; lack of bone rescue raised the hypothesis of poor engraftment, so a second transplantation was performed 1 year later. Full engraftment was documented by karyotype analysis and subsequently confirmed using DNA sequencing.

evidence.dc:description: Downgraded for insufficient clinical and family data. The curator contacted the authors for additional information which means the final score is pending.

Upgraded by 0.4 points for publication of x-rays showing severe bone phenotype. Please note, the final score for this proband is 0.6points. The 0.5 score cannot to adjusted due to the interface limitations.
Downgraded by 1.0 points because of consanguinity and homozygosity.

Not predicted to undergo NMD however, the mutation causes loss of the βG, βH and βF strands of TNFSF11, which is important for its trimerization. Ta et al. 2010 PMID: 21059944 confirmed the frameshift affected conformation and binding activity.

The mutation is seen in families 2 and 4 in this publication as well as families S5 and S6 in the Lo Iacono et al. 2013 PMID: 23762088 article. This variant is scored once to avoid overweighting it's impact to the disease.
Crockett et al 2011 PMID: 20458572 could not draw definitive conclusions regarding the possibility that the mutant products maintain a residual activity or rather completely lose their function.

evidence.rdfs:label: Sobacchi_Pt2A
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: significant reduction of medullary space, bone fractures

evidence.dc:description: Downgraded by 1.0 points for homozygosity and consanguinity.

A minigene-based approach found that the intronic mutation causes skipping of exon 7, resulting in an in-frame deletion encompassing amino acids 145–177. Ta et al.2010 PMID: 21059944 confirmed that the deletion of these amino acids abolished the interaction with RANK.

evidence.rdfs:label: Sobacchi_Pt1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: significant reduction of medullary space, occipital ischemia
